oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Teaching Pharmacokinetics to Veterinary Medical Students: Use of Computer-Assisted Instruction
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Conzelman, Gaylord M.
Brown, Crawford
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: pharmacokinetics
computer model
dosage regimen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
I wanted to model to be a “hands-on” program that students could use independently for problem-solving exercises. The pharmacokinetics “package” which we give our first year students consists of four parts:
Two conventional lectures on pharmacokinetics. A wet laboratory in which student groups determine the apparent volume of distribution and the half-life of a sulfonamide in the dog. A demonstration period:
How to operate the terminal. Brief description of model with list of assumptions.
Active drug was administered. The plasma is in equilibrium with all parts of Vd. Rapid distribution of drug in a single volume of distribution (Vd). First-order absorption and first-order elimination.
Plug in data collected in wet laboratory and let the program generate a plasma [ ] vs. time graph. Solving a few dosage regimen problems together.
A “home-work” assignment. The following is an abbreviated version of the demonstration I give my students.
